summary: This is a Virgin Islands Daily News article reporting on JPMorgan Chase's $290 million tentative settlement with Jeffrey Epstein's victims and related legal developments. It also covers the U.S. Virgin Islands government's lawsuit against JPMorgan and allegations that the government is withholding embarrassing documents about officials' interactions with Epstein.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Deceased financier and accused sex trafficker
persons.context: The central figure in the case; his abuse of teenage girls and young women over approximately 15 years led to the lawsuits against JPMorgan and Deutsche Bank. He was a client of both banks.

persons.name: Matthew Goldstein
persons.context: New York Times reporter credited as the source for the JPMorgan settlement story within this Virgin Islands Daily News article.

persons.name: David Boies
persons.context: One of the lead attorneys representing Epstein's victims in the lawsuit against JPMorgan Chase. He announced the $290 million tentative settlement.

persons.name: Jamie Dimon
persons.context: Sat for a daylong deposition roughly two weeks before the settlement, where he claimed he had barely heard of Epstein before Epstein's 2019 arrest.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Mentioned as having been convicted in 2021 in Manhattan federal court for helping Epstein engage in sex trafficking.

persons.name: Jed Rakoff
persons.context: Judge presiding over the lawsuits, including the victims' settlement with JPMorgan and the related lawsuit by the U.S. Virgin Islands government. He must approve the settlements.

persons.name: Suzanne Carlson
persons.context: Author of the section of the article detailing the U.S. Virgin Islands government's efforts to withhold documents related to Epstein.

persons.name: Cecile deJongh
persons.role: Former First Lady of the U.S. Virgin Islands
persons.context: Reported to have worked as Epstein's employee for 20 years and had close contact with him.

persons.name: Stacey Plaskett
persons.role: U.S. Virgin Islands Delegate to Congress
persons.context: Acknowledged in a May 9 deposition that she met privately with Epstein several times to solicit campaign contributions. She was the V.I. Economic Development Authority attorney from 2007 to 2012.

persons.name: Bryan
persons.role: Chairman of the V.I. Economic Development Authority (EDA)
persons.context: Served as EDA chairman while Stacey Plaskett was the EDA attorney and while Epstein, a convicted sex offender, was living in the Virgin Islands.

persons.name: Ellsworth
persons.context: Filed a motion arguing the U.S. Virgin Islands government is improperly sealing public records that are merely embarrassing to officials who dealt with Epstein, not confidential.

connections.description: JPMorgan provided banking services for Epstein from roughly 1998 to 2013, keeping him as a client despite red flags and designating him a 'high risk client' in 2006.
Maxwell was convicted in 2021 for helping Epstein engage in sex trafficking.
deJongh worked as Epstein's employee for 20 years and had close contact with him.
Plaskett met privately with Epstein several times to solicit campaign contributions.
Boies is one of the lead lawyers representing the victims in the lawsuit against JPMorgan.

The V.I. government is suing JPMorgan, claiming the bank kept Epstein as a client despite suspicious activity. JPMorgan's attorney (Ellsworth) is accusing the V.I. government of withholding embarrassing documents.

events.title: JPMorgan Announces Tentative $290M Settlement
events.description: JPMorgan Chase and lawyers for Epstein's victims announce an agreement in principle to settle a lawsuit for $290 million. The settlement awaits court approval.

events.title: Epstein's Florida Guilty Plea
events.description: Epstein pleaded guilty in a Florida case to soliciting prostitution from a teenage girl and registered as a sex offender.

events.title: Epstein's Arrest on Federal Charges
events.description: Epstein was arrested in July 2019 on federal sex trafficking charges.

events.title: Epstein's Death in Jail
events.description: Epstein killed himself in a Manhattan jail cell a month after his arrest.

events.title: Ghislaine Maxwell Conviction
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell was convicted in Manhattan federal court for helping Epstein engage in sex trafficking.

events.title: Stacey Plaskett Deposition
events.description: U.S. Virgin Islands Delegate Stacey Plaskett was deposed and acknowledged meeting privately with Epstein several times to solicit campaign contributions.

events.title: Deutsche Bank $75M Settlement
events.description: The same lawyers for Epstein's victims negotiated a tentative $75 million settlement with Deutsche Bank, which succeeded JPMorgan as Epstein's banker.

keyFacts: JPMorgan Chase reached a tentative $290 million settlement with victims of Jeffrey Epstein to resolve a lawsuit alleging the bank ignored warnings about his sex trafficking.
The lawsuit claimed JPMorgan kept Epstein as a client from 1998 to 2013 despite designating him 'high risk' in 2006 and numerous suspicious activity reports about large cash withdrawals.

The U.S. Virgin Islands government is separately suing JPMorgan and is accused by the bank's attorney of improperly sealing public records that are 'embarrassing' to V.I. officials who dealt with Epstein.
V.I. officials named in connection with Epstein include former First Lady Cecile deJongh (his employee for 20 years) and Congresswoman Stacey Plaskett (who solicited campaign contributions from him).
Deutsche Bank, which succeeded JPMorgan as Epstein's banker, also reached a tentative $75 million settlement with victims last month.
